feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 30 at 10:37PM EDT until August 31 at 1:45AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of central Indiana, including the following counties, Hamilton, Hancock and Marion.
* WHEN...Until 145 AM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1037 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 0.25 and 0.75 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Indianapolis, Carmel, Fishers, Noblesville, Lawrence, Beech Grove, Speedway, Southport, Westfield, Cumberland, McCordsville, Meridian Hills, Warren Park, Homecroft, Rocky Ripple, Williams Creek, Crows Nest, North Crows Nest, Castleton and Indiana State Fairgrounds. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hamilton, IN; Hancock, IN; Marion, IN

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 145 AM EDT SATURDAY

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 30 at 10:29PM EDT until September 2 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary:
* WHAT...High wave action, strong currents, and dangerous swimming conditions expected. Piers will be heavily swamped by waves.
* WHERE...In Indiana, Northern La Porte county. In Michigan, Northern Berrien and Southern Berrien counties.
* WHEN...From Sunday morning through Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...Strong currents can pull swimmers into deeper water and high waves can sweep people off piers.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern La Porte; Northern Berrien; Southern Berrien

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY MORNING THROUGH MONDAY MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 30 at 10:27PM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
At 1027 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from near Carmel to near Beech Grove. Movement was northeast at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Indianapolis, Carmel, Fishers, Noblesville, Lawrence, Cumberland, McCordsville, Fortville, Warren Park, Williams Creek, Geist Reservoir, and Castleton.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 69 between mile markers 200 and 214. Interstate 70 between mile markers 87 and 101.

cap:parameter.value: Strong thunderstorms will impact portions of southwestern Madison, northwestern Hancock, northeastern Marion and southeastern Hamilton Counties through 1100 PM EDT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 30 at 10:24PM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
At 1024 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from 7 miles southwest of Tipton to Noblesville. Movement was northeast at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Noblesville, Tipton, Cicero, Arcadia, Atlanta, and Morse Reservoir.

cap:parameter.value: Strong thunderstorms will impact portions of northeastern Hamilton and eastern Tipton Counties through 1100 PM EDT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 30 at 10:19PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
At 1018 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a thunderstorm with frequent lightning 9 miles southwest of Rock Hill, or near Mcconnells, moving south at 20 mph.
Locations to be impacted include... Rock Hill, York, Chester, Newport, Mcconnells, Richburg, Lowrys, Chester State Park, Sharon, and Edgemoor.
Torrential rainfall rates up to 3 inches per hour will be possible in these areas.

cap:parameter.value: A THUNDERSTORM WITH FREQUENT LIGHTNING WILL IMPACT CHESTER AND SOUTHWESTERN YORK COUNTIES UNTIL 1100 PM EDT

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 30 at 10:18PM EDT until August 31 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
...Observed flooding changed to Minor severity for the following rivers in North Carolina...
Green Mill Run At Green Mill Run in Greenville affecting Pitt County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring.
* WHERE...Green Mill Run at Green Mill Run in Greenville.
* WHEN...Until late tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 7.5 feet, Water likely covers portions of Charles Boulevard adjacent to the stream. The driveway for Bower Apartments becomes inundated with several feet of water, and is likely impassable. Water also spreads to portions of Ficklen Drive and Deck Street, and inundates portions of ECU College Hill parking lot.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:10 PM EDT Friday the stage was 7.6 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:10 PM EDT Friday was 7.6 feet. - Forecast...No forecast is available for this location. - Flood stage is 7.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TONIGHT

entry.summary:
At 1010 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of thunderstorms with frequent lightning 7 miles northeast of Gaffney, or near Earl, moving west at 30 mph.
Locations to be impacted include... Shelby, Gaffney, Spartanburg, Boiling Springs NC, Pacolet, Cowpens, Blacksburg, Mayo, Chesnee, and Pacolet Mills.
In addition to frequent lightning, torrential rainfall rates up to 3 inches per hour will be possible in these areas.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 30 at 10:01PM EDT until August 31 at 1:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of piedmont North Carolina, including the following county, Gaston.
* WHEN...Until 100 AM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1001 PM EDT, Heavy rainfall from thunderstorms resulted in 1.5 to 2.5 inches of rain that fell over a very short time. Subsequent runoff has resulted in a rapid rise on Catawba Creek with the creek rising above minor flood stage at East Hudson Boulevard. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.2 to 0.5 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Gastonia and South Gastonia. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

* WHERE...Huron River near Hamburg.
* WHEN...Until further notice.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 30 at 7:47PM MDT until August 30 at 9:30PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
entry.summary:
At 747 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... West El Paso, Central El Paso, East El Paso, Mission Valley, Sunland Park and Fort Bliss.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dona Ana, NM; El Paso, TX

cap:parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 930 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR SOUTHEASTERN DONA ANA AND WEST CENTRAL EL PASO
NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 9:30 PM MDT. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 9:30 PM MDT. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 30 at 8:30PM CDT until August 30 at 10:30PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:

Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Trained spotters reported.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Midland and Midland Airpark.
This includes Interstate 20 between mile markers 132 and 141.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 30 at 9:25PM EDT until August 31 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
FFWAKQ
The National Weather Service in Wakefield has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... North Central Gates County in northeastern North Carolina... The City of Suffolk in southeastern Virginia...
* Until midnight EDT tonight.
* At 925 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen since 840 pm. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 1.75 inches in 30 minutes through 10 pm.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Suffolk, Gates, Drum Hill, Reynoldson, Somerton, Buckland and Hazelton.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Gates, NC; City of Suffolk, VA

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 30 at 9:11PM EDT until September 1 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Tampa Bay Ruskin FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Florida...
Horse Creek Near Arcadia at SR 72 affecting DeSoto County.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Myakka River At Myakka River State Park affecting Sarasota County.
For the Myakka...including Myakka River State Park...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Horse Creek...including Arcadia at SR 72...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Horse Creek near Arcadia at SR 72.
* WHEN...Until early Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, The access road to Hidden Acres is impassable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Friday the stage was 12.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Friday was 12.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 12.3 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.3 feet on 08/09/1957. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 30 at 9:09PM EDT until September 6 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Columbia, Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until Friday, September 06.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EDT Friday the stage was 18.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage Friday, September 06 and continue falling to 16.9 feet Friday, September 06. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 06

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 30 at 8:53PM EDT until August 31 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Waccamaw River At Conway affecting Horry County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Waccamaw River at Conway.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Water will begin to cause minor flooding of yards and a few roads in the Lees Landing, Pitch Landing, Savannah Bluff, and Riverfront South communities. Areas along Waccamaw CIR and Riverside DR may also begin to flood. Low areas along Gray Oaks Drive may begin to flood. Access to Hidden River RD may be cutoff. Overflow of vast uninhabited swamp and natural boat landings will occur.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:15 PM EDT Friday the stage was 11.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage just after midnight tonight and continue falling to 9.2 feet Wednesday evening. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:

* WHERE...A portion of piedmont North Carolina, including the following county, Mecklenburg.
* WHEN...Until 1145 PM EDT.

This has resulted in rises on several streams including McMullen Creek above Lincrest Place and Little Sugar Creek at the Medical Center. Water from McMullen Creek may flood across Addison Drive, especially if the creek rises to 8 feet. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Uptown Charlotte, Central Charlotte, South Charlotte, East Charlotte, Northeast Charlotte, Southwest Charlotte, Northwest Charlotte, Matthews, Mint Hill, Weddington, Stallings, Pineville, Harrisburg, Marvin, The Plaza, Freedom Park, Southpark Mall, Hidden Valley, The Arboretum and Reedy Creek Park. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued August 30 at 8:23PM EDT until September 1 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level expected in low lying areas due to tidal flooding.
* WHERE...Shoreline in Anne Arundel County.
* WHEN...From 1 AM Saturday to 8 AM EDT Sunday, especially around the time of high tide.
* IMPACTS...At 2.8 feet, flooding of some of the parking area near Dock Street in Annapolis may occur, with water surrounding the Alex Haley Memorial.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides one to one and a half feet above normal. The next high tide at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy is at 4:30AM and 4:07 PM.

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM SATURDAY TO 8 AM EDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 30 at 4:10PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Ozone Action Day Alert.
WHERE...Douglas, Jefferson, Denver, western Arapahoe, western Adams, Broomfield, Boulder, Larimer, and Weld Counties
WHEN...400 PM Friday August 30 to 400 PM Saturday August 31
IMPACTS...Ozone Action Day Alert is now in effect for the Front Range Urban Corridor. Request to limit driving gas and diesel- powered vehicles is now in effect until at least 4 p.m. Saturday, August 31, 2024. Hot, stagnant weather will allow ozone to reach the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category on Friday and Saturday.For areas included in this advisory that are not expected to reach the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (USG) air quality designation, we request that activities, such as driving non-ZEV vehicles (i.e., gas or diesel), be reduced to lessen the impacts on neighboring air quality. Additional air pollution in this region may directly worsen air quality or contribute to precursors which may also adversely affect air quality. For Colorado air quality conditions, forecasts and advisories, visit: https://www.colorado.gov/airquality/colorado_summary.aspx
HEALTH INFORMATION...Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms and breathing discomfort in active children and adults and people with lung disease, such as asthma. Active children and adults, and people with lung disease, such as asthma, should reduce prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Boulder, CO; Weld, CO; Adams, CO; Denver, CO; Jefferson, CO; Douglas, CO; Arapahoe, CO; Broomfield, CO; Larimer, CO

cap:parameter.value: OZONE ACTION DAY ALERT FROM 400 PM FRIDAY UNTIL 400 PM SATURDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 30 at 1:50PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
RAIN CONTINUES WITH RATES AND INTENSITY INCREASING FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY. EXPECT RATES TO DECREASE LATE SATURDAY BUT RAINFALL WILL CONTINUE INTO SUNDAY. HEAVIEST RAIN WILL FAVOR THE CENTRAL PORTION OF THE PANHANDLE - ALONG AND NORTH OF SUMNER STRAIT TO FREDERICK SOUND INCLUDING PORT ALEXANDER, KAKE, PETERSBURG, WRANGELL, AND NORTHERN PRINCE OF WALES ISLAND. SITKA STILL REMAINS ON THE NORTHERN EDGE OF WHERE HEAVY RAIN COULD FALL.OVERALL, FORECAST RAINFALL AMOUNTS BETWEEN 3 TO 7 INCHES ARE EXPECTED, WITH HIGHEST AMOUNTS IN THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS.
FOR AREAS SOUTH OF SUMNER STRAIT, FORECAST RAINFALL TOTALS BETWEEN 2 TO 4 INCHES ARE EXPECTED.
NORTH OF FREDERICK SOUND TO THE ICY STRAIT AREA, FORECAST RAINFALL TOTALS BETWEEN 2 TO 5 INCHES ARE EXPECTED.
NORTH OF ICY STRAIT, FORECAST RAINFALL TOTALS UP TO 1 TO 2 INCHES ARE EXPECTED.
FOR THE NORTHEAST COAST, NEAR YAKUTAT, RAINFALL TOTALS UP TO 2 INCHES ARE EXPECTED.
RIVERS AND STREAMS WILL SEE RISES IN LEVELS BUT NO FLOODING IS EXPECTED AT THIS TIME.
TO PREPARE: AT HOME CHECK THAT SUMP PUMPS ARE OPERATIONAL AND KEEP GUTTERS CLEAR. ON ROADWAYS WATCH FOR DEBRIS CLOGING STREET DRAINS. BOAT OWNERS SHOULD CHECK BILGE PUMPS.
STAY TUNED FOR UPDATES AS THE FORECAST CONTINUES TO EVOLVE.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Yakutat; Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

entry.title: Excessive Heat Watch issued August 30 at 5:14PM AST until September 1 at 4:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A period of dangerously hot and humid conditions is possible. This level of heat could affect anyone without effective cooling and/or adequate hydration.
* WHERE...In Puerto Rico, Ponce and Vicinity County. In Virgin Islands, St Croix County.
* WHEN...From Saturday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Heat related illnesses increase significantly during extreme heat and high humidity events.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Excessive heat hazard risks may continue early next week. According to local standards, issuing an Excessive Heat Warning for three or more consecutive days will officially classify this event as a Heat Wave.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued August 30 at 1:43PM PDT until September 2 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Reno has issued a Fire Weather Watch for gusty winds and low humidity, which is in effect from Monday afternoon through Monday evening.
* Affected Area...Fire Weather Zone 270 Surprise Valley California, Fire Weather Zone 278 Eastern Lassen County, Fire Weather Zone 420 Northern Sierra Front including Carson City, Douglas, Storey, Southern Washoe, Western Lyon, and Far Southern Lassen Counties and Fire Weather Zone 458 Northern Washoe County.
* Winds...Southwest winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts 30 to 40 mph.
* Humidity...9 to 15%
* Duration...3 to 6 hours.
* Impacts...The combination of gusty winds and low humidity can cause fire to rapidly grow in size and intensity before first responders can contain them.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 30 at 3:01PM CDT until August 31 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of southeast Louisiana and southern Mississippi that are generally along and south of the Interstate 10 and 12 corridor. The greatest threat will be across urban metro areas including New Orleans, Baton Rouge, Gulfport and Biloxi.
* WHEN...Through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:

* IMPACTS: Low Humidity...Unseasonably Warm Temperatures...and Gusty Southerly Wind could cause erratic fire behavior.
* AFFECTED AREA: In North Central WY...Fire Weather Zone 281.

* WIND: South to southeast 13 to 17 mph with gusts around 25 mph.
* HUMIDITY: 13 to 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES: Highs around 90.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued August 30 at 12:46PM MDT until September 1 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH FOR PORTIONS OF NORTHEAST WYOMING SUNDAY...
.Breezy southeast winds gusting over 30 mph, combined with relative humidities falling to around 15 percent would support critical fire weather conditions Sunday.
The National Weather Service in Rapid City has issued a Fire Weather Watch for gusty winds and low relative humidity, which is in effect from Sunday afternoon through Sunday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 314 Northern Campbell, 315 Southern Campbell, 316 Crook County Plains and 317 Weston County Plains.
* WINDS...Southeast 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity would produce critical fire weather conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Campbell; Southern Campbell; Crook County Plains; Weston County Plains
